documents.title: couple who met at day centre tie the knot
text: we 've been following the story of a couple who suffered life-changing injuries who were getting married today after they met at a day centre in great yarmouth which helps people rebuild their lives .

alison rose , who suffered head and other injuries in a horse riding accident in the mid-1980s , and trevor hazell married this morning at the great yarmouth register office at the town library with about 20 guests .
they met at centre 81 seven years ago .
alison told the bbc she loved trevor because he `` understands me and my disability '' .
after some really tough times , the new mr and mrs hazell are embarking on a new life together .
author: Nic Rigby
BBC News

documents.title: chief negotiator '70 % confident ' devolution will happen
text: the man who oversaw the devolution negotiations for norfolk and suffolk says he 's `` 70 % confident '' that the final deal will be approved by local councils .
under the plans the two counties will receive extra powers and money in return for having a directly-elected mayor .
suffolk businessman andy wood told me he understood people 's concerns , but said the deal was in both counties ' best interests .

`` this is a change to local government and a fundamental change to the way norfolk and suffolk has a relationship with central government , so i think it quite healthy that we have this public debate , '' he said .
`` but i hear people talking about poor connectivity , getting delayed on our roads and wanting to move us from a low wage , low productivity economy to something more vibrant .
`` this could change and that 's why residents should be supportive of this . ''
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: motorists ' stopped and grilled over new river bridge
text: a traffic census has been carried out in great yarmouth as part of the consultation on building a third river crossing .
drivers on marine parade and south quay were stopped and asked about the purpose of their journey , and where they were travelling from and to .

david allfrey , of norfolk county council 's highways department , says it 's important to have accurate details to help identify what the transport benefits would be in having the bridge over the river yare .
the information will form part of a business case to the government for the £ 140m crossing over the river , which would link the town 's two enterprise zones .

documents.title: how much to spend a penny ?
text: they cost £ 122,000 to build , but now a further £ 30,000 is being spent to remove the self-cleaning public loos from harleston .
it turns out that residents and visitors to the south norfolk town did n't like the automated toilets , fearing they would n't work and might get stuck .
the block , in bullock fair close , has also been vandalised .
kay mason-billig is in charge of the environment and recycling for south norfolk council .
she says with hindsight they should have just refurbished the old ones .
the old , conventional , block will be brought back into use - but the new loos wo n't go to waste .
we do n't have an exact location for them yet .
we 've asked people if they 'd like to tender to have them on their site .
there 's a possibility it could be taken to one of the gypsy and travellers sites so they get a new modern toilet block there . ''

text: norwich 's darren webster opens his campaign at the grand slam of darts in wolverhampton on saturday night against ian white .
webster has had a good year on the pdc tour , winning more than £ 70,000 in prize money .
he will also face phil taylor and daryl fitton in the group stages .

documents.title: three arrested over church lead thefts
text: police have arrested three men in connection with lead thefts .
the men , aged 21 , 28 and 30 and from london , were arrested in north walsham yesterday following a number of incidents where lead has been targeted on church roofs across the county .
all three are currently in custody at aylsham police investigation centre .

documents.title: wedding bells for couple with life-changing injuries
text: a couple who suffered life-changing injuries are getting married today after they met at a day centre in great yarmouth which helps people rebuild their lives .
alison rose suffered head and other injuries in a horse riding accident , when she was a 21-year-old live-in childcare nanny in the mid-1980s .
she spent nearly three weeks on life support in intensive care .
her employer had wanted her to teach the children to ride .
her groom , trevor hazell , was 18-years-old and on his rounds as a postman in surrey in the early 1970s when he was knocked over by a hit and run car driver .
he spent six months in hospital , and another four months at a specialist brain unit .
the couple , who met at centre 81 , will tie the knot in great yarmouth today in front of family and friends .
fellow centre member , michelle osbourne ( below with the couple ) will be alison 's bridesmaid and trevor 's identical twin brother will be his best man .
centre 81 provides provides skills and activities for 70 adults with a disability .
part of our job is to help people rebuild their lives and it is wonderful that they are going to be doing it together as a couple too . ''
author: Andrew Turner
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: picture : traffic queues on the a11
text: this was the scene earlier on the a11 - emma shawcross says it took her two hours and 30 minutes to get through the traffic between thetford and the mildenhall fiveways roundabout .
emma tells us the traffic had been intensified by the a11 being reduced to one lane approaching the roundabout , and drivers having to merge about half a mile earlier .
further south along the a11 , the southbound carriageway has reopened between barton mills and red lodge , following a collision just after midnight in which a woman died .
a 63-year-old man has been arrested in connection with that incident .

documents.title: library may bid for funding to record and display names of ww1 soldiers
text: over 100 years ago , when the zeppelin threat loomed over norfolk during world war one , soldiers were posted to king 's lynn to keep a watch for the raiders .
among those regiments were the queen 's own oxfordshire hussars and the bucks royal hussars .
they moved on after the summer of 1916 , to be replaced by the 3rd battalion norfolk regiment and the royal defence corps , and a welsh regiment in 1917 .
to pass the time , many of the men scratched their names and service numbers in one of their look-outs - the tower of the newly-built king 's lynn library .
librarian kevin hitchcock , who 's researched the stories behind some of the names , says the wall has suffered erosion over the years and the names need protecting .

in conjunction with the oxfordshire yeomanry association , the soldiers of oxfordshire museum and the buckinghamshire military museum , we 're hoping to make a joint bid for lottery funding to record the names and recreate the wall to make it accessible for museums and libraries everywhere . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: a11 update - southbound carriageway now open
text: police have just told us the a11 southbound carriageway at red lodge has reopened , following a collision around midnight in which a woman in her early 20s died .

documents.title: second vehicle involved in a11 fatality
text: a man has been arrested on sus of causing death by dangerous driving , drink driving , and failing to stop following a road traffic collision , in connection with the death of a woman in her early 20s .
her citroen was found off the a11 at red lodge just after midnight .
police say their investigation into the woman 's death discovered that a second vehicle had been involved .
a jaguar was recovered , and a 63-year-old man from the brandon area arrested just after 04:00 .
witnesses to any incident late last night , in this area of the a11 , are asked to contact police on 101 .
the a11 is expected to remain closed , with diversions in place , until `` early afternoon '' while investigation work continues .

documents.title: the stories of the king 's lynn men who 'suffered terrible losses ' in ww1
text: king 's lynn librarian kevin hitchcock is researching the stories behind the soldiers who scratched their initials into the brickwork of the king 's lynn library tower in 1916 .
soldiers from the queen 's own oxfordshire hussars ( qooh ) and the royal bucks hussar ( rbh ) were posted to the town to keep a watch for raiders .
they moved on in the summer of 1916 , with many fighting in the battle of the somme .
with the help of the soldiers of oxfordshire museum , and a date-by-date diary written by one of the men stationed at king 's lynn , kevin says they know the fates of many of the men .
he said : `` they went over the top on 7 october 1916 and suffered terrible losses .
quite a few of the names on the tower were either killed or injured on that very date . ''
this is their only memorial .
it 's a wonderful record of those men .
some of them actually came to king 's lynn to join up and then found themselves on the frontline in france . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: roll of honour moves to new home on armistice day
text: a roll of honour listing the names of more than 3,500 men from norwich who died in world war one will be officially unveiled at its new home of city hall .
the event began with a service at the war memorial on st peters street , led by the rev robert avery of st peter mancroft church .
the recently conserved roll of honour will be blessed and dedicated by the bishop of norwich , graham james , following the two-minute silence .
when sir edwin lutyens designed the norwich war memorial in st peter 's street ( here ) , it was clear it would not be large enough to contain so many names .
so he designed a roll of honour on oak panels bearing their names .

it consists of an oak case with doors containing 12 double-died hinged , and four fixed single-sided panels , painted with the names and units of those killed , and was installed in norwich castle keep in 1931 .
it has recently undergone conservation work , and will be relocated to the foyer of city hall where visitors will be able to view it by appointment .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: unique history of soldiers who fought in world war one
text: a unique record of some of the soldiers who lost their lives at the battle of the somme 100 years ago is being researched in king 's lynn .

soldiers posted to the town as look-outs for zeppelin raids or an invasion , scratched their names and service numbers on the sides of the bricks and stones at the top of the crenelated tower of the newly-built library .
most of the men were from the queen 's own oxfordshire hussars ( qooh ) and the royal bucks hussars ( rbh ) , and were billeted with local families whose own sons were serving elsewhere .
the soldiers were a great boon to the local economy - and there 's evidence of weddings to two local ladies .
after the summer of 1916 , the two regiments were posted to france , with most of them fighting in the battle of the somme .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: eadie not surprised by canaries ' problems
text: former norwich city winger darren eadie says the club 's recent poor run of form should n't come as a surprise .
the canaries have n't won any of their last five games and have slipped from top of the championship to fifth and are now 10 points behind leaders newcastle .
eadie joined us on the scrimmage on bbc radio norfolk last night and said : `` there 's a huge problem .
`` they 've been pretty poor for 18 months in terms of the way they set the team up and the way they play . ''
you can download a podcast of the scrimmage .

documents.title: video : cottage industry in poppy day products
text: november - the month of remembrance , and many of us are wearing a poppy .
but the traditional paper version is n't the only one available - martin roberts has a mini-cottage industry in poppy-decorated items at his shop near ludham .
here you can find the poppy symbol on a variety of products , from mouse mats to mugs , cushions and clothes .
martin served in the army and knows how hard it can be for veterans .
all the money raised goes to the royal british legion .

documents.title: meeting to discuss future of academy
text: the academy chain run by the diocese of ely took over the ten mile bank primary school ten months ago , saying they would secure its future .
but parents in the west norfolk village have now discovered the diocese plans to close the school , and pupils will be sent to the neighbouring hilgay riverside academy instead .
both schools come under the diocese of ely multi-academy trust ( demat ) .
it has sent us a statement , confirming it 's looking at proposals for the future of ten mile bank school .

it said : `` following an initial meeting on 3 november , 2016 to discuss the future of the school with parents and carers , a further open meeting will be held on 22 november , 2016 from 18:30 to 20:00 at ten mile bank school , to which all members of the local community are invited . ''
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: dismay over 'scandalous ' possible closure of village school
text: a village school near downham market is under threat of closure , just 10 months after it became an academy .
the ten mile bank school became an academy on 1 january as part of the diocese of ely multi-academy trust ( demat ) .
but parents have now been told diocese wants to shut the school , with pupils being sent to hilgay riverside academy instead .
andy greening heard the news at a parents ' evening when he overheard another parent discussing it .
he told me his daughter loves the school , is getting on well with the teachers and learning well .
he said : `` she says she does n't want to go to hilgay .
that 's the reaction of all the children . ''

a former chairman of the school governors , colin wills , said norfolk county council had supported the village 's small school `` very , very well they threw everything at it for ten months they 've had it as an academy and for some reason it 's now not viable '' .
it 's important for our community as well as our children we 're an isolated community with no shop , no pub , and for it close it in the way it 's being done is quite frankly scandalous . ''
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: the public 's right to access information
text: by law , we all have the right to make freedom of information ( foi ) requests to government departments and public authorities .
campaigners and journalists often use them to find out things the people in power do n't want you to know .
for example , foi was used to expose the mps expenses scandal .
if you make a foi request , you 're supposed to get an answer within 20 working days .
most councils in norfolk do that - but an investigation by the bbc radio norfolk 's nick conrad show has found that norwich city council has only managed this 43 % of the time last year .

maurice frankel of the campaign for freedom of information says there 's something `` seriously wrong at the council 's end if they 're dealing with such a high proportion of requests so late in the day '' .
mike stonard is a labour councillor for norwich city council .
he tells us the council has now taken action to improve the situation .

documents.title: diss auctioneer raises the hammer for hos appeal
text: elizabeth talbot , director of diss auction house t w gaze , has been invited to be auctioneer at east anglia 's children 's hos ( each ) gala dinner in aid of the nook appeal .
the event , at the natural history musuem in london on wednesday , 30 november , will be the only live concert of the year by ed sheeran .

the international singer-songwriter , from framlingham , suffolk , is an ambassador of the charity - and earlier this week a drum kit donated by him reached £ 2,600 at a global online auction in aid of the appeal .
each needs to raise £ 10m for the the nook , a purpose-built hos woodland to the south of norwich , to replace its quidenham facility in south norfolk .
ms talbot , who 's featured on various bbc television programmes , says it was an honour to be involved in the gala dinner .

i have had the privilege of conducting many significant charity auctions all over the country , but this will rank as the most exclusive i hope to be able to encourage lots of generous bidding on behalf of this amazing charity .
what a night in store ! ''

documents.title: devolution deal : 'decide in two weeks '
text: devolution deal : 'decide in two weeks '
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC East political correspondent

documents.title: devolution : a significant moment
text: tomorrow 's publication of the government 's draft plans for devolution is a key moment on the rocky road to giving more westminster powers to regional authorities .

it shows that , despite four councils in norfolk pulling out of the process and widespread criticism from some people of the public consultation , the government has still decided to push ahead with the plans .
this could be the start of a major change in local government , but this is not yet a done deal .

every council in suffolk and the four authorities in norfolk which are still in the process will have to approve the deal over the next two weeks and , given the scenes we saw at norfolk county council on monday , that is by no means certain .
critics will also ask how devolution can work with the two main economic powerhouses in norfolk - great yarmouth and norwich ( not part of the project .
but the government is making it very clear that areas which are not part of devolution will get less funding in the future , that threat may just win round the critics .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: devolution negotiator : 'funding will go elsewhere if we say no '
text: the man who 's overseen the negotiations for norfolk and suffolk devolution has said he 's been told by the government that if local councils reject the plans next week `` the funding on offer will be spent elsewhere in the country '' .

andy wood , the boss of adnams brewery in southwold , has described the deal as `` one of the most ambitious devolution deals in the country '' but added that it was important that all the councils involved in the process vote to continue to back it .
under the plans the two counties will have :
four councils in norfolk have already pulled out of the devolution process .
the draft orders will say that they can re-join at a later date if they have a change of heart .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: mountain bike instructor 'to blame ' for tragedy
text: a solicitor left paralysed after falling on his head during a mountain biking course is likely to get millions of pounds in compensation after a court ruled his instructor was to blame .
leon maclean , of edinburgh road , norwich was paid by asif ahmed for a beginners ' course in the surrey hills four years ago .
mr ahmed , 47 , who still works as a senior lawyer , hit his head after hurtling over the handlebars of his bike on the notoriously steep holmbury hill .

mr justice jeremy baker ruled that mr maclean was 80 % to blame for the tragedy , and was negligent in `` encouraging '' mr ahmed to ride `` at speed '' down the sharp slope without first assessing his biking skills .
mr maclean is still a leading mountain biking instructor and there was `` no reason to believe '' he was not a competent one , the court heard .
the former primary school teacher with a passion for mountain biking was `` not a reckless or authoritarian individual '' the judge said .

the judge ruled that mr ahmed , of greenwich high road , london , was 20 % responsible for his own misfortune in failing to raise doubts about his own abilities , but praised him for the `` considerable dignity '' with which he gave his evidence in court .
the amount of mr ahmed 's payout has yet to be decided , but is likely to be more than £ 3m .

documents.title: vintage plane crash pilot does n't remember anything from that day
text: maurice hammond , a pilot from eye who was seriously injured when his mustang plane crashed at hardwick airfield in south norfolk last month , does n't remember anything from the day of the accident in which his passenger died , according to a family friend .
nik coleman said : `` as with anybody who has been involved in any kind of accident where they have survived and somebody else has n't , he will be facing those challenges .
`` he has no memory of the day , in fact .
`` so he and the family are going to be working through those challenges over the coming weeks , months and years . ''

documents.title: crash pilot a 'badly injured person '
text: a friend of maurice hammond , the pilot whose vintage plane crashed at hardwick airfield near bungay last month , says he is still quite ill and a `` badly injured person '' .
nik coleman said mr hammond , who lives in eye , has a `` whole plethora of broken bones in his chest , ribs and so on '' .

he added : `` he has a couple of rods that were surgically inserted in his neck - that 's not because of any break , it is to support his skull during the healing process , because he was involved in a very substantial whiplash type of injury .
he has a very unpleasant burn to his back and has had a skin graft which is healing `` relatively satisfactorily '' , mr coleman said .

documents.title: video : special suits help shop staff understand difficulties of dementia
text: living with dementia can turn everyday tasks into a challenge even shopping can become too difficult .
staff at a supermarket in long stratton have been given special training to help them help customers .
author: Rob Sykes
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: safety measures to protect hospital patients from vomiting bug
text: the queen elizabeth hospital in king 's lynn is asking visitors who 've had vomiting or diarrhoea in the previous 72 hours to stay away .
an increasing number of incidents of norovirus has been seen in the community , and the west norfolk hospital is putting a number of measures in place to protect patients .
all visitors will now be asked to report to the nurse in charge of a department or service before seeing a patient .
norovirus is a food-borne infection which can be easily combated by simple measures such as hand-washing .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: video : poppy petal making to teach youngsters about remembrance
text: children from great yarmouth have been making poppies , to help them learn about the significance of the poppy as a symbol of remembrance .
services will be held in the town tomorrow on armistice day and on remembrance sunday in honour of service personnel who lost their lives in wars and conflicts .

during a festival of remembrance at the st george 's theatre on saturday , paper poppy petals made by children from st george 's primary and nursery schools will join others floating down from the ceiling during a two minute silence .
author: Andrew Turner
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: council to write to government department over issues with benefits payments
text: great yarmouth borough council has issued a statement , following claims that delays in universal credit payments have led to hundreds of council house tenants getting behind with the rent payments .

it said : `` it 's not possible to say for definite that universal credit has increased rent arrears , but this appears likely given the trend of falling arrears in years prior to the roll-out of the system , which started in great yarmouth in april 2016 .

`` the council is drafting a letter to the department for work and pensions ( dwp ) to highlight some of the specific issues that great yarmouth is facing as a digital pilot area for universal credit , which has been discussed by full council . ''
we 've had a statement from the dwp which says `` the reasons for the rent arrears are complex and to link it to welfare reform is misleading '' .

documents.title: eviction threat 'ca n't be lifted ' from tenants in rent arrears
text: council house rent is owed by 400 tenants in great yarmouth , and one of the town 's labour councillors blames the arrears on a new benefits system .
universal credit is normally rolled out in stages , but in the east norfolk town it 's being rolled out in one phase .

vice-chairman of the borough council 's housing committee , andy grant , who supports the idea of universal credit , says there have been difficulties , leading to a `` significant level of arrears '' .
the conservative councillor says the threat of eviction ca n't be lifted from tenants , as `` there are a few who 'll abuse the system and are known for doing it '' .

ultimately the judiciary decide , but with a backlog of court appearances the chances are eviction action will not be taken for at least three months of arrears , by which time the claimant would have received their universal credit and the council would have received their money . ''

documents.title: councillor blames benefits system for rent arrears
text: more than £ 80,000 is owed in rent to great yarmouth borough council , and it 's being blamed on the administration of a state benefit called universal credit .
the introduction of this system , which is being trialled in the town , sees a single monthly payment replacing six others benefits which include housing , paid directly into a claimant 's account .
the idea is that the recipient would learn to manage their budgets , instead of the council managing things like rent and council tax relief .
but labour councillor michael jeal says the roll-out has been a disaster , with no training or support , especially as some people have never dealt with large amounts of money in their lives .
if you were given £ 1,000 , or whatever it is a month , in your hand straightaway you would think christmas had come .
they 're trying to make people make budgets who 've never done budgets in their lives . ''

documents.title: 'no eviction ' if rent arrears are due to delays in benefit payments
text: the amount of council house rent arrears owed to great yarmouth borough council has increased since the roll out of universal credit , says ukip group leader kay grey .
councillor grey says it 's not just the council , but private landlords too , who are affected by delays in payments from the benefits system .
she 's not happy about the threat of eviction for tenants who get behind with their rent .
if the arrears are down to universal credit , they should n't be evicted - it 's not their fault . ''

documents.title: child neglect police officer dismissed from force
text: a norfolk police officer has been sacked for misconduct after being convicted of child neglect .
las month , pc robert warrent was sentenced to 30 months in prison .
a police misconduct hearing dismissed him from the force yesterday .
norfolk police says his behaviour was found to fall below the high standards expected .
author: Tom Baker
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: when will it end ? churches in hempnall , newton flotman and topcroft the latest targeted by lead thieves
text: just two weeks ago the diss express reported how a festival launch at st nicholas ' church in north lopham turned to shock when it was discovered lead had been stripped from the roof .
author: Diss Express

text: police investigate fatal house fire

text: 626-mile round trophy trip for swansea

documents.title: devolution : final plans published tomorrow
text: the government is expected to publish its final plans for devolution for norfolk and suffolk tomorrow .
it will then be up to those local authorities who have so far backed the scheme to give their final approval .
if they do , legislation will be laid before parliament at the end of the month allowing elections for a mayor to take place next may .
under the plans the government will give the new authority more than £ 100m for housing and £ 25m a year for the next 30 years for infrastructure .
the new mayor will also be responsible for transport and strategic planning in the two counties .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: high street competition judges in norwich today
text: does norwich have the best city centre in britain ?
today , judges from the great british high street competition are here to find out .
the area around the arcade and the castle mall is up against derby and bristol .
stefan gurney , executive director of the norwich business improvement district group , hopes the city will be `` recognised for its uniqueness it will be a real boost '' .
judges have a 50 % say on who wins the title - the public have the remaining say .
norwich is currently in second place , and voting closes in two weeks - so it 's over to you !
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: world cup speedway returns to norfolk
text: king 's lynn will once again play host to world cup speedway as great britain launch their campaign against australia , usa and czech republic in 2017 .
the adrian flux arena in west norfolk had played host to the british leg of the competition for six years before it was moved to the new national speedway stadium in manchester for 2016 .
the decision has been made to return to the home of the king 's lynn stars due to the big crowd in previous years .
the event takes place on the 1 july .
author: Phil Daley
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: suspects on the run after attempted church lead theft
text: two suspects are on the run after attempting to take lead from a church roof earlier today .
it 's believed the two men , in their 20s or 30s , were disturbed while at all saints church in scottow , north of coltishall , at around 02:15 .
damage was caused to the roof of the 15th century church , but no lead was taken .
norfolk police were called to the scene , and the two men made off on foot across fields and were last seen at around 03:00 .
ch insp ady porter says it 's highly likely the suspects have left the county .
their clothing is almost certainly going to be wet and dirty in appearance .
anyone on their morning journey to work who may have seen two men fitting this description is asked to call police on 999 . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: school closed due to heating failure
text: there 's no school today for pupils of the edward worlledge community primary school in great yarmouth .
there 's no heating .
technicians will be working to sort the problem out and the school hopes to reopen tomorrow ( friday ) .

documents.title: vintage plane crash pilot recovering at home
text: maurice hammond , who spent some time in intensive care at the norfolk and norwich hospital after his vintage plane crashed at hardwick airfield in norfolk , killing passenger john marshall , has returned to his home in eye .
family spokesman nik coleman says mr hammond is still on a `` long recovery road '' .
`` he has rods in his neck and is recovering from multiple broken bones , '' he has written on facebook .
`` [ he ] also has a painful burn to his back , and treatment for all of the above continues with support from the nnuh .
`` he 's also started a rigorous and often painful process of physical rehabilitation . ''
author: Kelly McCormack
BBC Radio Suffolk

documents.title: investigation into fatal fire
text: emergency services are investigating a fatal fire in great hockham .
the police and fire service were called to scotgate close at around 15:00 on wednesday .
one person died .
a cordon is in place , and fire investigators are expecting to be at the scene from 09:00 .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: thursday 's weather : sunshine and showers
text: there 'll be spells of sunshine through the day , but also scattered showers developing - , perhaps heavy and thundery at times .
it 'll be rather breezy too , with a top temperature of 9c ( 48f ) .
watch my full regional forecast here :
author: Elizabeth Rizzini
BBC Look East weather

documents.title: welcome back to norfolk live
text: hello and thanks for joining us for another day on bbc norfolk live .
we 're here with the latest news , travel , sport and weather updates for the county .
i 'm sure bbc weather watcher freddie the fenman was n't the only one who needed to scrape the ice of his car this morning - elizabeth rizzini will have the day 's forecast shortly .

if you have a photo you 'd like to share with us , or if there 's anything happening in your part of the county that you think the bbc 's news teams should know about - drop us an email , or get in touch on facebook or twitter .

documents.title: our local coverage for the day
text: regular updates for norfolk have now ended .
among the stories we covered today :
the team are back from 08:00 .
have a good evening .

documents.title: france 's highest honour bestowed on veteran
text: one of norfolk 's d-day veterans has been presented with the legion d'honneur .
the accolade is the highest decoration presented by the french government to thank those who risked their lives to liberate the country during world war two .
harry brown , who 's in his nineties , was given the honour at a special event held just for him in hunstanton .
he was just 19-years-old when he was in a motor torpedo boat supporting the attack on omaha beach , as a royal navy volunteer .
`` we were getting shelled and that went on for about three , four days , '' he said .
`` afterwards we ended up up all the dead men .
`` we were them from the water .
we were too busy to be frightened . ''
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: environmental credentials of uea 'knocked ' after rugby pitches get approval
text: earlier we told you that plans to build a set of rugby pitches next to the university of east anglia have been approved by planners at south norfolk .
the council gave it the go-ahead , despite almost 300 letters raising objections to the scheme .
uea lecturer rupert read , who 's also a member of the green party , says the plans will harm an important site for wildlife .
`` this is a matter of a wonderful space that 's potentially at risk of being devastated , '' he said .
`` uea 's reputation is at stake .
i feel a little bit less proud today to belong to uea , and our reputation as a place that takes the environment seriously has taken another knock . ''
author: Tom Baker
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: man jailed for sex offences against children
text: a 22-year-old man from gorleston has been jailed for two years for sex offences against children .

oliver richard lee , of newnham green , was sentenced at norwich crown court today after he pleaded guilty to three charges including two counts of attempting to incite a girl under the age of 13 to engage in sexual activity .
he was also found guilty of making indecent images .
in a statement , police said lee was arrested following a search of his address in june 2015 , when a number of electronic items including mobile phones and a laptop were seized .
chat-logs on the computer between lee and four people he believed to be underage girls were discovered .
they revealed lee asked them to provide naked and to perform various other sex acts .
lee has been placed on the sex offenders register for 10 years .
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: weather : showers will continue this evening
text: the showers will continue this evening , particularly across norfolk and parts of suffolk , but will gradually die out to leave clear spells overnight .
staying chilly with lows of 1c ( 34f ) .
tomorrow will start cold with patches of fog in places , particularly in norfolk .
brighter spells are forecast later in the morning , as high pressure builds from the west .
top temperature : 8c ( 46f ) .
weather has more details .
author: BBC Weather

documents.title: man charged with prison staff assaults
text: a prisoner will face assault charges after allegedly carrying out attacks on two members of staff at a prison in norfolk .
it 's understood that one of them was the governor of hmp waylan , paul cawkwell , who was assaulted in the prison canteen .
thomas howard , 34 , has been relocated to another prison following separate incidents on 23 and 27 july at hmp wayland .
he faces two counts of assault causing grievous bodily harm , norfolk police said , and is due to appear before magistrates on 18 november .
author: Paul Moseley
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: head teacher concerned by proposed axing of crossing patrols
text: earlier we told you about the county council 's plan to get rid of 38 crossing patrols to save money .
the council says the crossings are on roads that are relatively safe for children to cross .
but melodie fearns , the head teacher at st george 's primary school in great yarmouth , which could lose its crossing , believes children will be at risk .
`` our front gate leads almost directly onto the zebra crossing and children do tend to charge out away from their parents , '' she said .
`` having the lollipop lady standing here everyday does give us all peace of mind .
`` the cars race along this road and quite recently one of the families had their dog run over by a car . ''
author: Andrew Turner
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: man bailed in murder inquiry
text: a 21-year-old man who was arrested in connection with the murder of a man in norwich at the weekend has been released on police bail , pending further inquiries .
a seal remains in place at the property in bowers avenue , as the investigation into the murder of steve stannard continues .
he was killed shortly before 14:30 on saturday .
the arrested man , who is from london , is due to answer bail in great yarmouth in january .
det ch insp marie james said : `` we still have a number of inquiries to follow which include looking at a large amount of cctv and continuing our forensic examination of the property . ''

documents.title: missing man probably dead , coroner rules
text: missing man probably dead , coroner rules

documents.title: new rugby facility given approval
text: plans to build a new rugby ground near the uea in norwich have been approved .
councillors in south norfolk voted seven to four to allow the plans to go ahead , subject to conditions outlined in the legal agreement .
the plans have been put forward jointly by the university and norwich rugby football club , and will boast new sports pitches and an artificial field with floodlighting .
a new pavilion and club house , with parking for 168 cars and 100 cycles , are also planned .
the plans have been controversial on ecological and environmental grounds , with concern also expressed about the impact on other nearby sports clubs .
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: king 's lynn businesses to pay levy to promote town
text: king 's lynn is to get a business improvement district , barring any major objections .
firms in the town centre have voted 53 % in favour of creating the bid , which would see them paying money on top of their business rates to fund improvements in the town .
lucy golding , owner of the market bistro , says it will help get the word out about the town .
`` i speak to a lot of people in king 's lynn who 've never been to the town before and they 're amazed how beautiful this town is , '' she said .
`` if we can get this message out to many more people it 's just going to have a massive positive effect on the town . ''
author: Tom Baker
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: thirty-eight school crossings could be cut
text: there are plans to get rid of 38 road crossing patrols outside schools , to save money .
the county council supports 96 crossings , but says 38 patrols are n't needed as the roads are relatively safe to cross .
it cost £ 245,000 to man the crossings this year , and the council plans to save £ 74,000 by reducing the number of patrols .
legally the responsibility for getting a child to and from school safely sits with the parent or guardian , not norfolk county council .
subject to further consultation , the cuts will be made by april .
author: Tom Baker
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: three radio stations to merge
text: three radio stations serving the norfolk and suffolk coast are going to merge .
anglian radio owns radio norwich , north norfolk radio and the beach - covering lowestoft and great yarmouth .
at the moment each station has its own programmes throughout the day , but soon all shows will come from norwich .
anglian has told the regulator ofcom this will save money and that one radio station will be more viable .
even though it effectively wants to close two stations , the company says it 's committed to localness and will have a new newsroom in norwich .
ofcom 's approved the merger , but it 's not clear when it will go ahead or how many jobs are affected .
author: Paul Moseley
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: dutch erosion scheme welcomed for bacton
text: tonnes of sand could be used in an attempt to slow down coastal erosion at bacton .
the owners of the gas terminal which supplies a third of the uk 's gas want to employ the dutch process of sandscaping to protect the site .
north norfolk district council is being asked to put £ 500,000 towards the £ 30m project .
councillor angie fitch-tillet says the work would help protect the village , which was battered in the tidal surge of 2013 .
`` the best form of coastal defence is a beach , '' she said .
`` in order to give more strength you put more sand on it , and it takes the sting out of the waves . ''
with regards to sandscaping , malcolm kerby ( chairman of the coastal concern action group , said : `` i 've seen it first-hand in the netherlands and it is fantastic .
`` not only does it create a superb beach it also creates a dune system .
they let nature do it . ''

documents.title: reports of child sex abuse overtake burglaries , police boss says
text: norfolk 's top police officer says sexual abuse has overtaken reports of burglaries in the county .

chief constable simon bailey , the national police lead on child abuse , said new figures from the children 's charity the nspcc which showed 500,000 men in the uk had viewed child sexual images online were probably accurate .
the charity says the figure is higher than previous police estimates .
mr bailey said : `` eight men a month are being arrested .
i now have to deal with more sexual offences on a daily basis than i do with burglary .
`` for the last 24 hours we 've had three burglaries .
i will not be surprised if we 've had seven or eight sexual offences reported .
we on average are submitting children at risk forms 1,500 times a month . ''
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: phone-in reactions to trump win
text: want to have your say on donald trump 's presidential win ?
radio norfolk 's phone-in with nick conrad is red-hot this morning as folks call to express their thoughts on trump 's victory .
the reaction so far , as you would expect , has been mixed .
some callers are worried about the `` mexican wall '' being built , saying it 's a bad day for `` race issues '' .
but others say finally , the will and views of neglected working-class people have been heard .
you can also let us know your views via email , twitter or facebook .

documents.title: uea professor describes trump as 'dangerous '
text: dr michael frazer , a new yorker who teaches social and political theory at the uea in norwich , says donald trump 's victory will be a real threat to the american democratic system , as his personality is `` incredibly troubling '' .
`` if trump does what he says he will do then this will be the most dangerous situation that the world has faced in my lifetime , '' he said .
`` he 's said he will not defend nato allies if they 're under threat from russia .
he 's said that he wants to see nuclear weapons in the hands of many .
many more countries .
`` the question is , does he mean what he says ? ''

documents.title: american foreign policy will see 'period of calm '
text: ingo wagenknecht , a norfolk environmental campaigner , told the bbc in january that donald trump would win the presidency .
speaking to nick conrad on bbc radio norfolk this morning , mr wagenknecht said the us had been fractured since the 1970s , with the divide between rich and poor widening ever since .
mr wagenknecht says although he 's not a trump supporter , he could see that trump managed to connect with ordinary americans personally rather than on policy .
`` the issues did not come up very much , '' he said .
`` i think trump is going to calm down quite a lot now .
he will come up with his own programme .
`` how much he involves the washington elite is another matter .
but on foreign policy we are in for a period of calm , with fewer interventions . ''
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: us election result causing ripples in norfolk
text: as you 've probably heard , one of the most bitter and divisive us elections for generations has ended in a huge political upset .
donald trump has confounded the pollsters to become the 45th president of the united states .
news of his victory has been met with mixed reaction from americans living in norfolk .
riki evans johnson is from new york and founded the east anglian american club .
she lives in sheringham but her daughters and grandchildren are in the us .
her family knew the kennedys and she was hoping for a clinton victory :
`` i 'm absolutely dumb-founded , '' she said .
`` i fell asleep for three hours and this is what i woke up to . ''
meanwhile , the broadland mp keith simpson , who 's on parliament 's intelligence and security committee , has described donald trump 's win as `` seismic '' .

`` this was a man with no political experience , never served in any political office , business record rather patchy , makes outrageous comments , takes on the republican party establishment and leaves many leading republicans saying they were actually going to vote for hilary clinton . ''
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: great weather for ducks
text: today will be rather cold and wet as rain , which may be heavy in places , makes very slow progress eastwards , perhaps briefly giving some sleet in the morning .
maximum temperature 6c ( 42f ) .

documents.title: welcome back to norfolk live
text: it 's been quite a night for our cousins across the water .
love him or hate him , donald trump has won the race for the white house after voters gambled on his promise to `` make america great again '' .
in his victory speech , mr trump said `` now is time to bind the nation '' and pledged to be president to all americans .
we 'll bring you local reaction to this unprecedented news , plus of course details of all stories affecting the county .
we 'd love to hear your views on the us election result , send them via the usual way - twitter , facebook or email .

documents.title: king 's lynn run joins forces with cancer charity
text: the grand east anglia run of 2017 has a new charity partner , with organisers run for all taking over the staging .
run for all is part of the legacy of the late jane tomlinson cbe , who raised nearly £ 2m for charity through a series of endurance challenges , despite being diagnosed with incurable cancer .
in a partnership with west norfolk borough council and alive leisure , the leeds-based charity aims to make the festival bigger and better in future years .
the event takes place in king 's lynn on sunday , 30 april and entries are open .

documents.title: colchester youth boss takes norwich job
text: colchester youth boss takes norwich job

documents.title: mp 'quietly confident ' of swanton morley base 's future
text: swanton morley falls in the constituency of conservative mp george freeman .
he 's given his reaction to the ministry of defence 's decision to sell off 56 bases within the next 25 years , including the robertson barracks at swanton morley in 2031 .
`` it 's part of our programme of investment in a modern armed forces , which includes new fighter jets for raf marham .
i 'm quietly confident that swanton morley will remain a base in the long-term .

`` i 'll be talking to ministers to make the point about why it 's such a strong facility and why , here in norfolk at marham and in swanton morley , we 're perfectly poised to support joint operations and to support that 21st century integrated rapid reaction force which is at the heart of our defence policy .
`` we 're home to fast jets at marham and the dragoons at swanton morley , and that 's a partnership i think that 's stood the test of time .
`` i 'm committed to making sure that continues in 15 years time we 'll be in a very different world and i think swanton morley will be in a very strong position .
`` we have a strong bond with our forces in norfolk and i 'm confident that legacy will last and our long partnership with the armed forces will continue many decades ahead . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: mother of missing man pleads for anyone with information to come forward
text: the mother of a man who disappeared after a night out in wisbech says someone must know what happened to him .
terry mcspadden , from elm in west norfolk , was 24 when he went missing after he 'd been at the locomotive pub in march 2007 .
today an inquest at norfolk coroner 's court recorded an open verdict .
speaking outside the court , his mother helen thrower says they were pleased with the outcome of the inquest and the police have not dropped the case .
if anybody knows anything about what happened to terry or where his body could possibly be , please , please tell somebody . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: delivery suites close under pressure
text: earlier we told you how some expectant mothers had been sent to hospitals outside the county for specialist care , due to increased pressures on the maternity unit at the norfolk and norwich university hospital .
the hospital 's delivery suite has closed to new admissions seven times since the beginning of may .
but the norwich hospital is n't the only one of the county 's hospitals affected by increased demand .
the queen elizabeth hospital in king 's lynn tell us their delivery suite has closed to new admissions five times in the last six months .

documents.title: horses deaths 'linked to fireworks '
text: the deaths of two rescued horses at a sanctuary this weekend are believed to be linked to fireworks .
staff from the redwings horse sanctuary found 19-year-old welsh pony sprite lying down in his field on saturday evening , suffering from suspected colic ( abdominal pain ) .
vet dawn trayhorn says this could have been brought on by the stress of him and his group charging around the field , after loud fireworks were let off nearby .
`` despite treatment and the efforts of his field mates pawing at sprite to encourage him to get up , he was unable to stand our only choice was to put him down , '' she said .
during early morning checks of the field at piggots farm the following day , another pony - percy - was found with injuries to his right front leg , and in a great deal of pain .
ms trayhorn says the injuries to the palomino could have been caused while he was running around at high speed , falling or even being kicked by another pony in distress .
they could n't make the 25-year-old pony comfortable , and said that again there was no choice other than to put him to sleep .
the sanctuary 's chief executive lynn cutress says the ponies were much-loved and long-term residents of redwings , and had both come as welfare rescue cases .

both ponies were in their latter stages of life and normally very sedate so this behaviour is highly unusual and ty of stress although we can never know for sure , it is likely the incidents were as a result of nearby fireworks displays . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: missing man investigation remains open
text: an inquest into the death of a man whose body has never been found is `` unusual '' say norfolk police .
terry mcspadden , who lived in elm disappeared after a night out at the locomotive pub in wisbech in march 2007 .
det ch insp marie james says the case remains unsolved , and while it 's not an active investigation they would review accordingly any new information received .
at this present time all lines of inquiry have been exhausted so unless new information comes to light , there 's no further progress we can make , '' she said .
over time loyalties change and relationships alter , there maybe someone willing to offer information now who did n't feel able to at the time .
i would urge these people to come forward so we can get to the truth for his family . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: inquest into death of man whose body has not been found
text: an open verdict has been recorded into the death of a west norfolk man who disappeared after a night out nine years ago .
father-of-two terry mcspadden , from elm , had been on a night out in wisbech .
norfolk coroner 's court ruled that 24-year-old mr mcspadden died in elm near wisbech , but there was no sufficient evidence to know the medical cause of death because his body has never been found .
the date of death was given as 2 march 2007 .
mr mcspadden was last seen at 01:00 that morning .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: more time to question man arrested over murder
text: police have been given a further 36 hours to question a 21-year-old man who was arrested in connection with the murder of a man in norwich at the weekend .
investigations continue after officers were called to bowers avenue , in the north of the city , shortly after 14:30 on saturday following reports a man needed medical assistance .
the victim , steve stannard , who was 37 , died at the scene .
a cordon remains in place at the property while inquiries continues .
we would still like to hear from members of the public who witnessed anything or may have information relating to it .
we 've increased patrols in the area to reassure the local community and are working closely with forensically trained officers to get a full of what happened . ''

documents.title: initiative to highlight tech corridor
text: a new campaign has been launched at westminster to draw attention to norfolk 's growing importance when it comes to research and development .
local politicians and business leaders say the `` cambridge-norwich corridor '' is already home to 12,000 high tech firms and could be worth £ 0.5bn to the economy if it 's allowed to develop .
the campaign , which was hosted by the mp for south west norfolk , elizabeth truss , is appealing to ministers for more investment in the county .
ms truss said : `` the corridor is about setting out a clear 15-year plan for more jobs and more growth .
`` we have great universities and research institutes .
we want to see businesses developing from that , with people staying in norfolk and helping build up our economy . ''
the completed dualling of the a11 brought many new businesses to the county , she added , but more and better infrastructure is needed and other roads , like the a47 , need upgrading .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: optimism over closure of barracks
text: `` keep calm , and carry on '' - that 's the message from the chairman of swanton morley parish council after the news that robertson barracks is to close by 2031 .

roger atterwill says the closure is a long way off , and at the moment they 're putting in a neighbourhood development plan for the future growth of the village over the next 20 years , and the base 's closure comes into that period .
he told me that he does n't expect the closure will have too much of a negative impact - the village 's amenities and schools would be able to stand on their own two feet .

if and when it does shut , it has enormous possibilities - 250 houses on site which we hope would be an opportunity for local people to move into them and a wealth of technical buildings which provide opportunities for new businesses to grow . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: it 's safe to dip your toes into norfolk 's seas
text: norfolk 's bathing beaches have all passed the test for water quality .
the county has 16 spots for bathing , and the quality of the water at each site has been rated by defra as either good or excellent .
the only place where the rating has changed year on year is at wells where the water quality has gone from excellent to good .
author: Nanette Aldous
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: ed sheeran 's signed drum kit raises more than £ 2,600 for each
text: a drum kit owned by singer/songwriter ed sheeran when he was a teenager , has been sold for £ 2,650 in an online auction raising money for east anglia 's children 's hos
the framlingham superstar has regularly supported the charity , which is currently raising funds for a new hos in norfolk which will be called the nook .
graham butland , each chief executive , said : `` we are thrilled that this generous gift from our ambassador ed sheeran has raised such a fantastic amount through this high profile auction .

`` not only will the money raised through the auction take us one step closer to our vision [ of ] a 21st century building for 21st century care for families in norfolk , but it has also helped to raise the profile of the vital care we provide to life-threatened children and young people . ''

documents.title: maternity unit 'prioritises complex care cases at times of high demand '
text: now back to our story on pressures on maternity services at the norfolk and norwich university hospital ( nnuh ) , which has seen some expectant mothers having to go out of the county for specialist care .

the neonatal intensive care unit ( nicu ) has 42 cots , and is one of three specialist tertiary units in the east of england providing care for nearly 900 sick and premature babies each year from norfolk , suffolk and further afield .

the hospital 's chief operating officer , richard parker , says the unit has been on a heightened state of alert on 12 occasions in the past six months , and while the unit does not close , demand for service is managed by admitting the most premature and sick babies in need of very specialist care .
the delivery suite was closed to new admissions seven times since the beginning of may 2016 , he added , and on these occasions women in need of complex care would have been prioritised .
those with more straightforward pregnancies were asked to deliver their babies at another hospital .

this is not a decision we take lightly and we recognise the impact it can have when women have made their plans our priority is to deliver a safe service and match the patient 's level of clinical need to the service which can best support them . ''

documents.title: mod base closures : retired general calls it 'money saving '
text: retired senior british army officer general the lord dannatt says the ministry of defence announcement that it 's to close 56 bases over the next 25 years is `` a further roll of the dice as far as changes to our defence policy is concerned '' .
`` it 's the mod trying to save money by having a smaller army , '' he said .
`` it 's part of a plan to get rid of single unit stations and to put military units into super garrisons - colchester is very much one of those super garrisons .
`` it 's disappointing for civilians who have jobs at those stations .
i hope that those affected will find other jobs locally . ''
in the eastern region , the mod 's closure plans include rock barracks near woodbridge , carver barracks near saffron walden and robertson barracks in swanton morley .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: norwich stars go back to school
text: norwich stars go back to school

documents.title: strictly star to turn on city 's christmas lights
text: canaries chairman ed balls will step off the strictly dance floor and onto the steps of city hall to turn on the christmas lights for norwich .
the former shadow chancellor , who was born in norwich and is a lifelong canaries fan , says it 's an honour to turn on the lights in his home town .
the switch-on takes place on thursday , 17 november , with an evening of entertainment starting at 18:00 , including projections and illuminations , a light juggling show and singers .
santa will set off from the anglican cathedral , accompanied by carol singers - arriving at the forum to take children 's christmas letters .
ed will be switching on the lights at 19:00 , following by stunning projections set to music on norwich castle and city hall .

i 'm so thrilled to be part of what promises to be a spectacular evening and also get the chance to say thank you to everyone who has supported me on my strictly journey - i could n't have done it without you . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: maternity unit facing increased demand for service
text: the norfolk and norwich university hospital ( nnuh ) says it 's seen an increase in demand as women have babies later in life , or have complications because of obesity .
national guidance on managing pregnancies has also led to an increase in the number of women being induced .
lisa brophy , the chairwoman of the maternity service liaison committee , works to help improve services for patients at the hospital .
she says services are very stretched , and a new level of intervention is needed to reduce the stillbirth rate , adding that a stretched service asked to do more will not cope very well .
i always hear really positive things about the staff , but i also hear from midwives who do a 12 hour shift and do n't even have time to go to the toilet .
if you 're that busy then you ca n't give that sort of level of care consistently . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: greater anglia one of the worst performing operators , mp says
text: greater anglia rail is still one of the `` worst performing '' operators - three months after it secured the new franchise to run the service , parliament has been told .
the colchester mp will quince told the boss of abellio greater anglia what he thinks of the firm 's service , after his train to london ran 30 minutes late yesterday .
the conservative , who sits on the commons transport committee , says customers are fed up with the number of trains in our region being delayed and cancelled .
the managing director of abellio greater anglia , jamie burles , said `` billions of pounds '' are being invested in new trains to improve performance .

documents.title: expectant mum faced 120 miles trip due to bed shortage fears
text: an expectant mother from norfolk whose contractions started two months early was told she could face being transferred more than 120 miles to watford .
gemma spalding , from loddon , went into labour at 30 weeks .

because her baby was likely to need a bed on the neonatal intensive care unit at the norfolk and norwich university hospital - which was full - she says staff had to call 14 other hospitals to try and find a space for her .
gemma , 24 , who has a one-year-old son , says it was `` very upsetting , quite stressful '' and would have been a long way for friends and family to travel .
she was given medication which stopped her contractions , so that she did n't need to make the journey to watford in the end .
she is now 36 weeks pregnant .

one of the doctors i spoke to on my follow-up appointment said that the woman they saw after me was taken to leeds the staff are brilliant , but everyone 's so stretched they 're having to send people all over the country . ''

documents.title: demand for maternity services sees some mothers sent out of county
text: pressures on maternity services at the norfolk and norwich university hospital have led to some expectant mothers being sent as far as london and leeds for care .
the hospital 's neo-natal intensive care unit has been on a heightened state of alert on 12 occasions in the past six months , which means some woman have been asked to go to another hospital .
the delivery suite has also been full and forced to close to new patients seven times in the past six months .
the hospital , which deals with almost 6,000 births a year says it 's recruited 17 new midwives in the last three months .
its chief operating officer richard parker says they work with other hospitals when there 's a peak in demand , to keep services safe and `` ensure all patients receive the care they need '' .
author: Nikki Fox
BBC Look East

documents.title: closure of army base 'a sad day '
text: keith simpson mp , whose constituency included the robertson barracks at swanton morley until 2010 , says the announcement of its closure is `` a sad day '' .
the mp for broadland , who regularly speaks in debates on defence and security , says there has been a succession of regiments at swanton morley .
`` the soldiers have mixed very well with the local community and enjoyed being in norfolk i do n't know how many millions of pounds they bring into the local community , '' he said .
he is concerned at what will happen to the base .
we 've seen a succession of mainly raf bases closing over the last 20-30 years and the fear is the mod wo n't be able to dispose of it .
we do n't want to have a base left derelict and open to vandals . ''

documents.title: home of one of army 's oldest regiments to close
text: the queen 's dragoons guards ( qdg ) took up its new home at robertson barracks in swanton morley following a 14-year deployment in germany .
the prince of wales is colonel-in-chief of the qdg , and in february he visited the regiment , meeting soldiers and presenting medals .
the regiment is one of the oldest in the army , with the cavalry unit 's lineage going back more than 300 years .
they fought on horseback at the battle of waterloo .
their role today is one of reconnaissance , in light armoured vehicles , scouting ahead and passing back vital intelligence to fighting troops .
they have seen action in iraq and three tours in afghanistan - its 450 soldiers were among the last to leave the war-torn country .
yesterday , the ministry of defence announced the closure of the swanton morley barracks by 2031 , as part of its cost-cutting measures .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: ex-norwich boss : i can get wolves promoted
text: new wolverhampton wanderers manager paul lambert says his club can get promoted to the premier league this season .
the midlands team are currently 19th and 20 points off top spot .
former norwich city boss lambert begins his reign at preston a week on saturday .
i do n't see why we ca n't make a run at it .
there 's a lot of games still to play .
we will try to put a run on and win games . ''
author: Rob Butler
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: defence land sell off 'biggest shake up since ww2 '
text: yesterday , the government announced it was selling off 56 more defence sites by 2040 as part of a review of ministry of defence land .
in total , around 2 % of uk land mass is taken up by the mod and it takes a lot to maintain .

there 's no word where these units , including carver barracks in essex , robertson barracks in norfolk and rock barracks in suffolk , will be moved to , but it 's likely most of the land sold will be brought up by the commercial sector and housing developers .
this definitely is the biggest defence shake up since world war two .
author: Alex Dunlop
BBC Look East

documents.title: soldiers from suffolk barracks 'likely ' to move to colchester
text: hundreds of servicemen based in suffolk are facing the prospect of being moved out of the county , when plans announced by the ministry of defence come into effect .
raf barnham near thetford , which provides military housing , will close .
the announcement also means that 500 soldiers from 23 para engineers at rock barracks near woodbridge ( will have to move out in 2027 .
there 's no word on where those units are going to move to , but i think it 's very likely that 23 para will move to colchester - that 's where 16 air assault brigade is based .
author: Alex Dunlop
BBC Look East

documents.title: army base to close
text: an army base in norfolk is among those being closed by the ministry of defence to save money .
the robertson barracks , at swanton morley near dereham , will shut by 2031 .
it 's the home of the queen 's dragoon guards , one of the most operationally experienced regiments in the army , having seen action in iraq and afghanistan .
their colonel-in-chief is the prince of wales
the unit itself is not being disbanded - it 's the barracks , training area and living space that will be shut .
yesterday the mod announced the closure of 56 bases over the next 25 years , with some of the land being used to build new homes .
raf marham is n't affected by the changes and will continue to be an active airbase .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

it should stay dry though , with sunny periods , although the cloud will increase and the temperature will peak at 5c ( 41f ) .

documents.title: good morning from norfolk live
text: hello and welcome back to norfolk live .

expectant mums at the norfolk and norwich university hospital have been sent as far away as london and leeds for care - more on this shortly , along with our regular news , sport , travel and weather updates .
and brrrrrrrr what a chilly start to the day - the weather forecast will be here soon - but first here 's a frosty taken by bbc weather watcher hopping frog .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: swanton morley base to close
text: the ministry of defence is close a further 56 sites as part of a cost-saving measure .
the changes will take place over the next 25 years , with some of the land being freed up to build up to 55,000 homes .
the robertson barracks at swanton morley is among the closures .
mod more to close : rock barracks , suffolk ( 2027 ) , carver barracks , essex ( 2031 ) , robertson barracks , norfolk ( 2031 ) , raf barnham , suffolk
rock barracks is brand new near enough .
disgraceful .

documents.title: our live coverage today
text: our regular updates have finished for the day - unless there 's a breaking story .

today we 've told you about the extraordinary meeting at county hall where councillors discussed the future of devolution - there were chaotic scenes as arguments broke out and the meeting was temporarily suspended .
in other news , a man found fatally injured in norwich at the weekend died of stab wounds , and norwich city councillors are looking at proposals for the regeneration of anglia square .
we 'll leave you with this photograph , taken by bbc weather watcher fishermanjames , of thousands of pink footed geese leaving the mud flats of the wash to graze on sugar beet fields .
large numbers of the birds spend the winter here , arriving from breeding grounds in iceland and greenland .

documents.title: mp says devolution 'dying on its feet '
text: the mp for north west norfolk has said devolution is `` dying on its feet '' and the county should come up with a better suggestion next year .
sir henry bellingham , conservative , said a directly-elected mayor would `` undermine mps , council leaders and the public would hate it '' .
sir henry said that devolution was in trouble in many other parts of the country because of the unpopularity of mayors .
`` it would also be a fifth tier of bureaucracy and , in a time of austerity , can we really ask people to vote for it ?
we 'd be laughed at by the electorate , '' he said .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: mental health abscondee seen in thetford store
text: john gladstone , who police are seeking after he failed to return to a low secure hospital ward in ipswich last week , has been seen at a store in thetford .
he was on `` town leave '' from the premises in foxhall road on tuesday , 1 november , with conditions to return to the unit by 15:30 on the same day , which he failed to comply with .

police say gladstone , 34 , who is subject to a detention under the mental health act and is on a life licence following conviction for offences of robbery and possession of a firearm , should not be approached by members of the public .

documents.title: go-ahead to develop former town centre store
text: plans for a new flagship store in king 's lynn shopping centre have been given planning permission today .
the shop would be on the site of the old beales store in the vancouver centre , and centre manager abby panks says it 's good news for the town .
the project will start in january , and the developers hope it will be open by christmas next year , although they are not revealing the name of the tenant .
at the same meeting , west norfolk borough councillors agreed to 11 homes being developed on the site of a former undertakers in london road , king 's lynn .
proposals for 50 more houses on the edge of west lynn were turned down , because they were outside the boundaries set by the local plan .
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: weather : very cold overnight and rain tomorrow
text: showers will continue to feed down the eastern side of the region overnight , but for many it will be dry .
there 's the chance of some mist and fog and it 's going to be cold .
temperatures in some spots could drop below freezing , so there 'll be a frost and possibly some icy patches .
it 'll be a cold and frosty start to tuesday .
cloud will eventually thicken from the west and some persistent rain will then move eastwards on tuesday evening and night .
temperatures on tuesday only reaching around 6c ( 43f ) .
there are more details on the bbc weather website .

BBC Look East weather

documents.title: region plays key role in record number of common cranes
text: the eastern region has been at the forefront of a successful breeding programme , which has seen a record-breaking 48 pairs of common cranes raise 15 chicks across the uk .
11 of those chicks were reared here in the east .
the fens in particular had a bumper year for cranes , with 8 pairs and 7 young recorded at locations including rspb reserves at nene washes and lakenheath fen .
the norfolk broads continues to be a stronghold for the birds with 11 pairs and 4 fledglings in 2016 .

ian robinson , chair of the uk crane working group , said : `` crane breeding success in the east reached a fantastic level in 2016 and if we could maintain this and replicate it in other regions as the re-introduction project matures , we could be looking at having a sustainable population of cranes in the uk for the first time in hundreds of years . ''

documents.title: new archdeacon of norwich excited by role 's variety
text: rev canon karen hutchinson is looking forward to thevariety of her new role as archdeacon of norwich and warden of readers , which will officially begin this sunday afternoon at a special service in norwich cathedral .
author: Network Norfolk

documents.title: suspended jail term for assaulting paramedic
text: a man has been given a suspended prison sentence for sexually assaulting a paramedic while she was on duty .
arturas gilys , 27 , of bagge road in gaywood , was sentenced at king 's lynn magistrates court on friday after admitting touching the woman in august .
he 's been sentenced to 16 weeks jail , suspended for 24 months .
the east of england ambulance service says it has a zero tolerance approach to any form of violence .
author: Tom Baker
BBC Radio Norfolk
